channel.title: User-friendly Deep Learning
channel.description: Making deep learning accessible to domain experts without having to rely on machine learning experts

item.title: Datasets website launched
item.dc:creator: University of Waikato
item.description:
Datasets used in our publications are being made publicly available on our dedicated website for datasets:

https://datasets.cms.waikato.ac.nz/ufdl/

item.title: Paper accepted
item.dc:creator: University of Waikato
item.description:
Our publication, Efficiently Correcting Machine Learning: Considering the Role of Example Ordering in Human-in-the-Loop Training of Image Classification Models, has been accepted in the 27th Annual Conference on Intelligent User Interfaces, Helsinki, Finland (March 21-25).

We will add the paper on our publications page, once the proceedings become available.

item.title: wai.annotations.yolo release
item.dc:creator: University of Waikato
item.description:
The newly released wai.annotations.yolo module for the wai.annotations library allows the reading and writing of annotations in a format used by the popular YOLO network architectures.

The wai.annotations release 0.7.4 has this new module as dependency (as well as the wai.annotations.imgaug module released last week).

item.title: wai.annotations.imgaug release
item.dc:creator: University of Waikato
item.description:
The newly released wai.annotations.imgaug module for the wai.annotations library offers some basic image augmentation techniques (crop, flip, gaussian-blur, hsl-grayscale, linear-contrast, rotate) which can be applied to the stream of images that are being processed in the pipeline. Of course, any annotations get processed accordingly. Under the hood, the excellent imgaug library is utilized.

At this stage, the module supports the following domains:

  • Image Classification Domain

  • Image Object-Detection Domain

item.title: wai.annotations modularized
item.dc:creator: University of Waikato
item.description:
A new release of wai.annotations is out: 0.7.1

The 0.7.x series saw a modularization happening behind the scenes, with each file format now being a separate repository and Python package. This makes it much easier to only include the relevant dependencies in ones virtual environment or docker image, keeping things as small as possible.

item.title: Docker-Compose for Backend
item.dc:creator: University of Waikato
item.description:
To further simplify the installation process, a docker-compose script has been compiled. This script now combines the Docker steps for setting up the PostgreSQL database, Redis and the actual backend.

Check out the updated Getting started page.

item.title: HTML Frontend for image classification
item.dc:creator: University of Waikato
item.description:
An experimental user interface for image classification is now available:

The interface is written in React and allows the user to incrementally improve their models until they are happy with the performance (human in the loop).

You can find out how to access this interface on the Getting started page.

item.title: Docker for backend
item.dc:creator: University of Waikato
item.description:
In order to simplify the steps necessary to set up the backend, Docker images for the PostgreSQL database, the Redis server and the actual backend have been created. These images get rebuilt every night to always have the latest code-base available, making it easy to stay up-to-date.

Head over to the Getting started page and have a look.

item.title: Detectron2 0.4 Docker image available
item.dc:creator: University of Waikato
item.description:
A new Docker image for building models with version 0.4 of Detectron2 is available:

More information on the Docker image is available from Github:

github.com/waikato-datamining/pytorch/tree/master/detectron2/0.4

item.title: Detectron2 Docker image available
item.dc:creator: University of Waikato
item.description:
A new Docker image for building models with Detectron2 is available:

More information on the Docker image is available from Github:

github.com/waikato-datamining/pytorch/tree/master/detectron2
